| Autoignition = LD50 = 227 mg/kg (rat, oral)
  }} }} 'Adenine' ('A', 'Ade') is a nucleobase (a purine derivative) with a
  variety of roles in biochemistry including cellular respiration, in the form
  of both the energy-rich adenosine triphosphate (ATP) and the cofactors
  nicotinamide adenine dinucleotide (NAD) and flavin adenine dinucleotide (FAD),
  and protein synthesis, as a chemical component of DNA and
  RNA. [http://ghr.nlm.nih.gov/ghr/glossary/adenine Definition of Adenine
  from the Genetics Home Reference] - National Institutes of Health The
  shape of adenine is complementary to either thymine in DNA or uracil in RNA.
